text:
Washington Bridge, spanning the Harlem River, from upper Manhattan; at (West 181st Street and Amsterdam Ave), to the Bronx. The photographers vantage point is in the latter and he is viewing towards the former. About 1932.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Bridges - Washington Bridge [spanning the Harlem River from upper Manhattan at West 181st Street and Amsterdam Avenue to the Bronx.]
North (Hudson) River - shore and skyline - George Washington Bridge.
North (Hudson) River - shore and skyline - George Washington Bridge.
North (Hudson) River - shore and skyline - George Washington Bridge.

text:
(1)
Highbridge Park: The pump house, set in a hollow between High Bridge and Washington Bridge. The latter appears partially on the right; photographers view being northward.

April 8, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, in the same direction and showing the general area. Buildings appearing on the left, line the western boundary of the Park, which at this point is Amsterdam Ave.

April 8, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: High Bridge Park - [Amsterdam Avenue.]

title: Manhattan: High Bridge Park - [Amsterdam Avenue.]

text:
The George Washington Bridge, a steel structure, connecting Manhattan at West 181st Street with Fort Lee, New Jersey. The view is westward from Manhattan, and just south of the Bridge. Control of this engineering masterpiece, is in the hands of the N.Y. Port Authority, who will charge a toll for crossing same. These 4 views are more or less similar, and are all by the same photographer.

1936.

Walter L. Bogert.
title: Bridges - George Washington Bridge - [Connecting Manhattan at West 181st Street with Fort Lee, New Jersey.]

text:
(1)
Harlem River Driveway, east side, south from (approximately) West 184th Street, showing the pedestrians walk and a portion of Highbridge Park. Also shown (left) is the Harlem River, and Washington and High Bridges spanning the river, linking Manhattan with the Bronx (left). Washington Bridge crosses the Harlem River at West 181st Street, and High Bridge at West 174th Street.
April 20, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, another view.
April 20, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Harlem River Driveway, east side, south from (approximately) West 184th Street, showing the pedestrians walk and a portion of Highbridge Park. Also shown (left) is the Harlem River, and Washington and High Bridges spanning the river, linking Manhattan with the Bronx (left). Washington Bridge crosses the Harlem River at West 181st Street, and High Bridge at West 174th Street.
April 20, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, another view.
April 20, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Riverside Park, north from West 135th Street, showing the marginal lands between same and the Hudson River. Traversing this strip are the New York Central Railroad tracks and the new elevated Henry Hudson Parkway, a feature of the vast West Side Improvement Project (q.v.).

To the left is the U. S. Training Ship "Illinois". This formerly was anchored at West 98th Street and only recently was removed here. Across the background is the George Washington Bridge, extending from West 181st Street, Manhattan to the Palisades of New Jersey.

P. L. Sperr

April 1, 1938
Views: 1-2

Riverside Park, north from West 135th Street, showing the marginal lands between same and the Hudson River. Traversing this strip are the New York Central Railroad tracks and the new elevated Henry Hudson Parkway, a feature of the vast West Side Improvement Project (q.v.).

To the left is the U. S. Training Ship "Illinois". This formerly was anchored at West 98th Street and only recently was removed here. Across the background is the George Washington Bridge, extending from West 181st Street, Manhattan to the Palisades of New Jersey.

P. L. Sperr

April 1, 1938
Views: 1-2

Washington Bridge, spanning the Harlem River and connecting W. 181st Street, Manhattan (left), with the Bronx. The views are north from High Bridge.

June 20, 1940
Views 1,2

P. L. Sperr
title: Bridges - Washington Bridge - Harlem River - [High Bridge.]

text:
